div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE

The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Venice every Wednesday about 8:30 a.m. in time for Express to Switzerland, Paris and London, leaving Venice 2 p.m. and 11:20 p.m. Arrival Trieste every Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Veinna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4:50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carraiges and luggage van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo at 9:30 a.m. and are conveyed directly to Quay alongside steamer.

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS.
div.p: CAIRO-KHARTOUM SUMMER MAIL SERVICE.

*Sleeping and Dining Cars. – During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Cars trains leave Cairo for Luxor on Wednesdays, Mondays and Saturdays at 6:30 p.m. and Luxor for Cairo on Sundays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 8:30 p.m.

From 1st of May 1906, these trains will be suppressed, but Dining and Sleeping Cars will be attached to the ordinary high trains from Cairo and Luxor three times a week, on the same above mentioned days.

The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: The weather yesterday was, to say the least, extraordinary for the month of May. Dark, threatening clouds, instead of the usual bright sunshine, prevailed in the early morning, and this was followed by rather heavy downpours of rain. In the afternoon the weather cleared up, but about 8 p.m. the wind veered to the west and a severe thunderstorm, accompanied by frequent and extraordinarily vivid flashes of lightning, passed over the town. Strong gales prevailed during the night, the force of the anemometer reaching 81 kil. The forecast for to-day is bright and warm, with probably showers and wind.

MONDAY, MAY 14, 1906.

div.head: THE SULTAN’S SURRENDER.
div.p: The news of the Sultan’s decision to evacuate Tabah in compliance with the argent demands pat forward by the British Government was a decided relief to all in Cairo who have been in any way connected with the negotiations, which have been both delicate and protracted. A-noDg Europeans the general feeling is that British prestige will be greatly enhanced in the Ottoman Empire and indeed in all Moslem countries, Egypt included, and that the British Government and its representatives will reap a gratifying reward for their firmness. Whether the Porto had agreed the frontier of the Firman of 1892 was unknown at the time of writing, bat it was generally believed that these concessions and any others demanded by Great Britain in the ultimatum—or "pen-ultimatum” — would be granted by the Porte. Rumours went about Cairo on Saturday prophesying rioting and what not on Sunday or Monday. There was little direct evidence that any outbreak or demonstration had been organised. As a rule the stories were based on the blood-curdling hints of Berbereen who had bean found sharpening knives or the more appalling language of cabmer, but there can be no doubt that then was a certain amount of onrest on one side and a certain amount of apprehension on the other. To guard against any possibilities of the sort the British military authorities kept their troops confined to bar- racks and ready for instant work, but the quiet of a dull and lowering day was unbroken by the very slightest disturbance. The statement recently made by a con- temporary that a force was setting cut for El Arish is quite ins oo a rate. Kaimakam Parker Bey, who left for the frontier a few days ago, is the only addition to the garrison of the little border town, though perhaps our contrère wishes to point out that the gallant cffioer might be described as a host io himself. The Nekhl force numbered 100 coastguards. and leu than 40 soldiers, with two Maxims and a Krupp. The statement that certain units had been warned for service in the Sinai is, we are informed, inaccurate, and it was never intend- 1 ed to send British troops from Egypt to the front A considerable amount of speculation has been aroused by the surrender of the Porte as to the probable effect of recent events en the prestige of the Sultan. In our opinion it will suffer terribly. The Sultan and Khalif has been led by incompetent advisers into an impasse from which he has had to retire with difficulty and without dignity. Previous surrenders to naval demonstrations or threats of demonstra- tion had been made before the overwhelming force of the European Concert or in trifling commercial disputes or affaire connected, as a rule, with the status of protected subjects. Bat in the present dispute Abdul Hamid Khan has been compelled to give way before the pressure of a single Power, and though public opinion in Turkey is usually dormant, it may prove that the wounded pride of the Osmanli ruling caste may avenge itself on advisers of their sovereign. In Arabia, where the Sultan s authority is by no means firmly established, the news of the withdrawal from Tabah before a show of force will encourage the Yemen rebels and the Wahabis of Nejd. Yet if the Porte, abandoning a policy of useless aggres- sion at the expense of its neighbours, make a genuine attempt to improve the internal condi- tion of the Empire and to place its disorganised finances upon a sound basis, the Tabah inci- | dent may prove the beginning of a new and happier era for the last great independent Moslem State. We wish we could look with any confidence to such a result.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Land and Mortgage Co. of Egypt.
Tke directors recommend a dividend of 5 % for the six months ended March 31, making with the interim payment in November last, 10 for the year.
The Cronier Bills.
The sum of 1,000,000 francs, or nearly one fifth of the past year’s profits, has been set aside by the Connoil of the Union Parisienne Bank for one amortisation of the Cronier bills.
The Wreck of the Cairo.
The Genoa Peral Court has acquitted Captain De Marchi, the master of tin Rubattino S.S. Cairo, whioh was wrecked in Alexandria harbour in March last year, on the charge of negligence and incapacity.
Murder at Mariout.

The Native Court of Alexandria yesterday sentenced Aly Koureim Youssef, a native of Mariout, to fifteen years’ imprisonment with hard labour for having murdered Yaconb Mustapha, of the same district, on the 23rd April.
American Negroes in the Sudan.

The few negroes whom Mr. Leigh Hunt brought from the United States for his estate at Zeidab are doing wel1, and it is interesting to note that their relations with the natives are satisfactory. They work as blacksmiths, carpenters, etc.
San Stefano Casino.

We are asked by the management of the Casino to state that they cannot respond to applications for invitations to Saturday’s ball which are made by or for persons who are not abounds of the Casino. The ball is reserved for abounds and clients of the hotel and restaurant.
New Markaz.

The Ministry of the Interior has decided to abolish the Faraskour Markaz, Dakahlieh, and create a markaz in Damietta called the Damietta markaz, under the administration of the Goavernorat of that town. The new markaz, which will be inaugurated on the 1st prox., will administer the Damietta ooast villages and the old markaz of Faraskonr.
Lord Milner’s Testimonial.

A few forms for signatures for the testimonial to Lord Milner are at the disposal of persons wishing to sign the same at the Anglo-Egyptian Bank at Alexandria. Signatories must be British subjects, of the male sex, and over twenty-one years of age. The wording of the testimonial is such that persons of any political party can sign it without violating their principles.
Another Police Assault Case.

The Frenoh Consular Court has acquitted Youssef Ibrahim el Dabgah and the brothers Moussa Ibrahim Noubu and Farag Ibrahim Noubu, accused of striking Ibrahim Ilyaon and Moussa Ilyaon, of the secret police. The contradictory nature of the evidence given by the plaintiffs and the absence of all corroboration appeared to justify the decision of the Court.
Charity Performance,

A grand Franco-Italian gala soirée, pro- moted by the Dante Alighieri Society, aided by the other associations, will be given at the Zizinia Theatre on Thursday next, in aid of the sufferers by the Vesuvian and Courrières catastrophes. The performance, which is under the patronage of the Frenoh and Italian Consuls, promises to be most successful. Cer- tainly the programme, which consists of three comedies and vocal and instrumental music, is a most attractive one. Tiokets may be had at Romanelli’s bookstall, Old Bourse-street.

div.head: SULTAN SURRENDERS. FRONTIER CRISIS OVER. BRITISH CONDITIONS ACCEPTED. TURKISH TROOPS WITHDRAW.
div.p: London, May 12.
It is understood that there are grounds for hoping that the dispute with Turkey is on the eve of settlement.
Reuter
Constantinople, May 12.
The Porte has agreed to evaouate Tabah and all other places within Egyptian territory.
Reuter
Constantinople, May 13.
The Porte has accepted the British conditions in the Tabah question.
Havas
Constantinople, May 13.
The Turkish troops have evacuated Tabah.
Havas

We understand that the question of the delimitation of the frontier, which was, as our readers will remember, contained in the British demands, was not settled yesterday. The Porte’s answer to this demand is expected to be known in the course of the day. We need not point out the importance of this demand. The mere evacuation of Tabah and Rafah is not enongh, since without delimitation Turkish aggression might be repeated on the ploa that the ftontier was undefined at any moireat when the political situation appeared favourable.
Ghazi Mukhtar Paoha, the Imperial Ottoman High Commissioner, received the following official notification of the settlement of the Tabah question from Constantinople —

“As the occupation of Tabah by the Turkish troops was only intended to preserve the status quo in the Sinaitio Peninsola by pre- venting the erection of military fortifications, and as ths necessary guarantees have finally been received, the Ottoman Government has consequently issued orders to the Turk- ish troops to withdraw from Tabah to their original place, and they will be transported by the Diana. Negotiations are now pro- ceeding to secare a final settlement of the Sinai question.”
Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha paid a visit to the Khedive this morniDg and officially communicated to his Highness the decisions of the Sublime Porte in regard to the frontier dispute

div.head: NATIVE PRESS COMMENTS.
div.p: "Al-Lewa” welcomes the solution of the i difficulty, which it considers very satisfactory to Turkey, whose only object was to impede the construction of fortifications by England in the name of Egypt. Nothing remains, remarks “Al Lewa,” with relief, exoept to settle the limits of the Sioaitio Peninsula, which had hitherto been undefined ; but this is a question which can be easily settled. By its aotion the Ottoman Government has shown the whole world that Bhe is alive to her interests. She aims at making the Gulf of El-Akaba a military station, and is working day and night to complete the Hedjaz Railway, which is a vital vein in the body of the Ottoman Empire.

"Al Moayad,” while hoping that Tarkey has preserved her dignity in the arrangement concluded, is satisfied at the speedy solution of the Sinai question, owing to the relations of the Egyptians with the Occupation, whioh is predominant in this country, and on the other band, owing to the religious and political ties which bind them to Turkey, with which they have great sympathies. Had the crisis become more acute, concludes our contemporary, God knows what the consequences might have been.

Reuter’s telegrams, remarks "Al-Ommeh,” give one to understand that the Sublime Porte has agreed to evacuate Tabah unconditionally, but this is not in accordance with the real facts of the case. Sir E. Grey, the British Minister for Foreign Affairs, has declared that an international commission must be appointed to define the boundaries of the Sinai peninsula, and at the same time the Turkish troops will withdraw from Tabah. It seems, continues our contemporary, that the Ottoman Government believes that her rights will be preserved by arbitration, if the news of the temporary evacuation of Tabah by the Turkish troops is true. “The Sublime Porte,” concludes “Al-Ommeh,” “would not Surrender so easily in snoh a serious question anless its object were attained.”

div.head: EL ARISH.
div.p: Now that the frontier incident is over El Arish will lapse again into the insignificance of a desert frontier town. It has occasionally figured in history and had once to do with General Bonaparte. On the 17th of February, 1799, the Frenoh force engaged in the invasion of Syria arrived before it. Three days later the Turkish general surrendered. Gaza fell after a feeble defence, and some 800 of the El Arish garrison, who, it was alleged, had broken their parole, were included in the shooting of Jaffa. It was at El Arish, also, that Kléber and Sir Sydney Smith concluded, in the following year, that convention which was not to take effect. For Kléber, with his remnant of 12,000, fell upon the 70,000 Turks who were enveloping him, and ‘ in the most amazing fight the sun of Egypt ever saw,” swept that army out of existence.

div.head: TURKEY'S DISAPPOINTMENT. SULTAN STOOD ALONE. HIS DESIGNS ON EGYPT.
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service).
LONDON, Monday.

The “Daily Telegraph’s” Constantinople correspondent says that the Sultan was practically alone in opposing the British demands, no Turk of position or intelligence supporting him. All wish that England had come, not only to settle the Tabah question but to occupy Turkey.

The "Telegraph,” in its leading article, says that Great Britain stands guard in Egypt for two purposes — first, to defend the rights conferred upon her by unsurpassed works of constructive statesmanship which she has accomplished single-handed in the interests of the Egyptian people, and, secondly, the British regime on the Nile is a new guarantee of the interests of civilisation in the whole Pan- Islamic sphere. It is useless of “Yildiz" to dream of reconquering Cairo, and the Sultan, by continuing to work against Great Britain, can only end by bringing the whole of the elaborate fabric of his late policy to the ground.

The two Notes addressed in 1892 by Lord Cromer (then Sir Evelyn Baring) to Tigrane Pasha, Egyptian Minister for Foreign Affairs, and the Grand Vizier’s telegram to the Khedive, elucidating the terms of the Sultan’s Firman of Investiture, contain the statement of rights which the British Government has been upholding on behalf of Egypt and of Great Britain against the Porte. On the accession of the present Khedive in 1892 the customary Firman of Investiture from the 8ultan was found to differ from that issued to the late Khedive, Tewfik Pacha. As "no alteration can be made in the Firmans regulating the relations between the Sublime Porte and Egypt without the consent of the British Government,” Lord Cromer at once took up the subject with Tigrane Pasha, and a correspondence followed.

Previous firmans recognised the ancient limits of Egypt and the regions thereto annexed. The firman of 1892 omitted all mention of the regions annexed clause. The result of the correspondence is clearly and plainly set forth by Lord Cromer in his closing letter to Tigrane Pasha. The following passage sufficiently emphasises Great Britain’s position : —
“The late Firman, if read by itself, appeared j to imply that the Sinai peninsula would for the future depend administratively, not on the Khedivate of Egypt, but on the Vilayet of the Hedjaz.
“Her Majesty's Government signified to the Sublime Porte some weeks ago, through Her Majesty’s Charge d’Aftaires at Constantinople, their willingness to assent to this arrangement.

"Under these circumstances I am instructed to declare that Her Britannic Majesty’s Government consent to the definition of boundaries contained in the present Firman, as supplemented, amended, and explained by the telegram of the 8th inst. from His Highness the Grand Vizier, which theycoonsider as annexed to, and as forming part of, the Firman, and that they entertain no objection to the official promulgation of the Firman with the addition of the above-mentioned explanatory telegram.

“I am to add that Her Majesty’s Govern- ment cannot admit that any existing territorial rights or claims are in any degree affected by changes whioh have been introduced into the language of the Firman, or by their aooeptance thereof.”

div.head: MUKTAR PASHA.
div.p: Haydar Midhat Bey, in a letter to the “Tribune” remarks : — What astonishes me is that Lord Cromer, who, as I can affirm from an interview I had with him in the month of November or December, 1899, refused to recognize that Mukhtar Pasha enjoyed any other quality than that of a simple private gentleman of distinction living at Cairo, permitted him to treat with the Khedive a question in which the prestige of Great Britain was at stake, and, above all, that he permitted him to do so without him (Lord Cromer) being present.

div.head: BRITISH PRESTIGE.
div.p: The Bey continues :— Now, the question is whether that prestige will be restored in the East to what it was formerly by the Sultan’s yielding once more to the threats of a great Power. It is permissible to doubt it. At the time when the influence of England was preponderant in Turkey, Great Britain, in the eyes of the Turks, was of all the Powers the one which, by her constant efforts, proved best the interest she took in the moral and material regeneration of Turkey. At that time England considered that it was one of her greatest interests to preserve the independence of a Turkey regenerated by her aid. Is that the case to-day ? Is it logical to hope that a demonstration, of whioh one of the principal objects would not be the liberation of the Turks from a regime which weighs so heavily on them, will enlist the sympathies of the Turkish people ? Let those who in England protest against the oppression of peoples reply for me.

div.head: THE BRITISH DEMANDS. SIR E. GREY'S STATEMENT.
div.p: Mr. Balfour, rising at the olose of questions in the House of Commons last Monday, said : As the Secretary for Foreign Affairs is in his place, perhaps be will allow me to ask him a question with regard to the Egyptian Frontier. We on this side have been scrupulously oareful not to embarrass the Government by questions —(cheers) - but if it is consistent with the interests of the public service for the right hon. gentleman to give the House and the country information on the subject I am sure it will cause very general satisfaction. (Hear, hear.)

Sir E. Grey —I quite agree that after all that has appeared in the Press, and in view of the fact that a similar question is to be put in another place to-day, there should be some answer given to the House. The British Ambassador on Thursday last presented a Note to the Porte inviting the Sultan to agree to demarcation by Great Britain and Turkey of the line from El Rafeb to the head of the Gulf of Akaba on the basis of a telegram from the Grand Vizier to the Khedive of April 8, 1892, and pending a settlement to withdraw the troops from Tabah. In order to explain the Note 1 think I ought to give a short summary of what actually preceded it. Early in the year the Egyptian troops were sent in the ordinary course to occupy certain posts in the interior of the Sinai Peninsula, including Tabah on the western coast of the Gulf. On arrival at the latter post it was found that 150 Turkish troops were already in occupation. His Majesty's Government protested against the occupation by the Turks of Tabah, a place unquestionably within the Sinai Pen- insula, and poinfed out to the Porte that if any doubt existed as to the frontier line a Joint Delimitation Commission seemed the best solution of the question. On February 13 Lord Cromer reported that the Turkish Commandant at Akaba was demanding the withdrawal of the Egyptian troops from Faroun Island. This island is in the northern part of the Gulf of Akaba. His Majesty’s ship Diana was instraoted to proceed to Faroun to proteot the Egyptian post there. After farther representations the Saltan decided to send two officers from Constantinope to inquire into the matter, and they left for Egypt on February 20. It was hoped that the Commissioners would discuss the matter ot forming part of a Joint Delimitation Commission. These Commissioners, however, left Cairo and proceeded to Beyront without having communicated with the Egyp- tian Government, the Khedive, or Lord Cromer. On March 21 the Turkish Ambassador made a communication to the effect that as Tabah was a dependency of Akaba no objection could naturally be made to the presence three of Turkish troops, and that it was consequently unnecessary to send officials from Egypt to institute an inquiry into the question. The Saltan now authorised Mukhtar Pacha to negotiate with the Government of Egypt, and his Majesty’s Governmeat agreed to negotiations takiDg plaoe at Cairo. Mukhtar Pacha had an interview with the Khedive and demanded on behalf of his Government that the boundary of the Sinai Peninsula should ran from El Rafeh to Suez and from Suez to Akaba. The Khedive’s reply to these representations suggested that the telegram of April 8, 1892, should be taken as the basis of settlement, that the line should run from El Rafeh to Akaba, joining the ooast three miles west of Fort Akabs, and that the remainder of the line of frontier should be determined by competent surveyors. The Grand Vizier’s reply to the Khedive was to the effect (1) that the Gulf of Akaba and the Sinai Peninsnla were outside the territory defined iu the Imperial Finnan ; that the telegram of April 8, 1892, only referred to the western side of the Sinai Peninsula ; (3) that the interpretation of that telegram was a matter which only ooncerned the Imperial Ottoman Government; (4) that Akaba had been adopted as the headquarters of the Mutessarfieh of Akaba, and the hope was expressed that no occasion would be afforded for interference by any other Power. The delay, the extent of the demands which have been put forward, and the tone and character of the Tarkish communications to the Khedive have made it impossible to defer a settlement indefinitely. We are now pressing our original demand for a joint delimitation. The Note to which I have referred was drawn up before the violation of Egyptian territory at El Rafah. I stated on Tuesday that his Majesty’s ship Minerva had been sent to El Arish to ascertain whether the boundary pillars at El Rafeh had actually been disturbed. I regret to say that the report of the removal of the pillars has keen confirmed by the captain of the Minerva ; but as the Grand Vizier informed Sir Nioholas O’Conor that a Commission would be sent to replace the pillars had they been disturbed it does not appear neccesary to make any representation on that subject. I need hardly remind the House that the prime determining cause of the occupation of Egypt in 1882 was that the condition of unrest in that country threatened danger to the Suez Canal, and it is not to be supposed that having thus intervened to protect the Canal from danger coming from the western side, we shall now, 24 years after these events, be indifferent to similar dangers arising on the eastern side of the waterway. (Cheers.) I think I may claim on behalf if the Government that they have shown great patienoe and moderation ; but the latest development of the Turkish demands would, if admitted, place Turkey in a position which would be a real danger not only to the Suez Canal bnt also to the liberty of Egypt and the Khedivial Dynasty. His Majes'y’s Government cannot, therefore, be indifferent to such issues, and the importance of them makes it necessary to press for a settlement on the lines of the frontier of Egypt as it existed undisputed for many years.

div.head: SUAKIN NOTES. RAILWAY TRAFFIC RETURNS
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT
Suakin, May 9.

The traffic returns of the Sudan Government Railways for March, 1908, are about L.B. 15.000, which is nearly doable the amount for the corresponding month last year. A new large sambuk (dhow) was launched a few days ago from Graham’s Point belonging to A wad El Kareim Bew Shenawi, head of the Dative merchants here. This sambuk was started before the railways put the first rail down for the Suakin-Arbara line but the line was completed a good many months before the sambuk. Several of the prinoipal merchants were present at the launch.
The British steamer Celtic Princess arrived here on the 6th inst. from England with a special consignment of cement for the Sudan Government Railways and left again on the 8th inst for India.

The Sudan Customs are erecting some wooden sheds and offices at Graham’s Point opposite the piers, so that merchants can discharge their cargo on the piers and get them loaded direct into railway trucks for Khartoum toumand elsewhere, thus saving the enormous cost of porterage by having to take the merchandise to the town Custom House.

The following gentlemen went on their summer leave by the last Khedivial Mail liner Dakahlieh : Miralai Hawker Bey, Governor of the Red Sea Provinces ; Bimbashi Dunbar, Slavery Dept.; Mr. Mackenzie, Superintendent E.T.C., Suakin branch.

Mrs. Bonnici, the wife of Mr. J. Bonnici (Maltese, British subject), Asst. Distriot Loco. Supt., Suakin, gave birth to a sou at Graham's Point, and his name was registered at the Suakin Moadirieh as George Graham, born at Graham’s Point. This is the fourth birth registered at Graham’s Point, viz, 1 British, 1 Austrian, 1 Greek, and 1 Egyptian.

div.head: CAIRO "ZOO."
div.p: We have been favoured with a copy of the report of the Zoological Gardens of Ghizeh for 1905, which, as the report describes it, was the most important so far in the history of these gardens. The Government increased the subsidy by L.E.2,000, and this enabled certain long-wished for reforms to be carried out. The price of admission was lowered, and 177,587 people visited the gardens, 112,876 more than in any previous year, the gate receipts being L.E. 1,402. The stock of animals has been increased by over 200 head, including several very interesting species ; while the number of deaths was 255, as compared to 267 daring 1901. The collection of monkeys and lemurs, numbering 147 specimens representing 33 species, is probably one of the finest in the world. Another important feature is the large lawn on which the following characteristic Nile birds live together in a state of comparative freedom : whale-headed stork (3), saddle-billed stork (2), sacred ibis, crowned crane, demoiselle crane, grey crane, flamingoe, Egyptian goose, spur winged goose and brown-necked raven. On the 31st of March three very fine trees (Australian silk-oaks) were struck by lightning and killed : and in the last week in December much damage was done to thou- sands of the plants by frost, many of the showier tropical shrubs being destroyed. The finances of the "Zoo” are excellent, the accounts closing with a surplus. The list of donors is a long one, including names of Lord Carzon, Sir Vincent Corbett, Crookshank Fakry, Pacha, Sir William Garstin, Hussein Pacha Lewa Jakson Pacha,Prince eon Omar Poussoun, Lady O’Conor, Sir Edward Zohrab Pacha, etc. The satisfactory financial state of the institution and the good progress of the last year speak volumes for the administrative capabilities of the director, Captain Flower.

div.head: NEW CANONS INSTALLED.
div.p: On Sunday, 29th ult., the Lord Bishop in Jerusalem installed as honorary canons of the Collegiate Church of St. George-the-Martyr Revs. Robert Sterling and Johnston Carnegie Brown. The Bishop was attended by his Chaplain, the Rev. J. T. Parfil ; the other officiating clergy were the Sub-Dean (Canon Marriott), the Rev. S. Gould, M. D., and the Rev. C. A. Manley.

Canon Sterling graduated at Durham, and is a'80 M. B., Chir. B., and B. Soi. of Newcastle-on-Tyne College of Medicine. He has been head of the Medical Mission at Gaza since 1893 and has built there one of the most important hospitals in Palestine.
Canon Brown graduated at Cambridge and has been incumbent of Christ Church, Jerusalem, since 1901-2. He has done much to consolidate and develop the work of the London Jews Society in Jerusalem.

div.head: BAND PERFORMANCE.
div.p: The usual summer concerts by the British military bands in the Esbekieh Gardens will commence to-morrow evening, when the band of the 1st Batt. Lancashire Fusiliers (by kind permission of Colonel J. H. Gideon and officers) will play the following programme, commencing at 9 p.m. :—

E, N. Miles, Bandmaster.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Count Bernstorff, Councillor of the German Embassy in London, who has been appointee German Consul General at Cairo, was entertained to a farewell dinner at the German Athenaeum last week. Many notable German residents in London were present, together with most of the personnel of the Embassy. Count Berastorff has since left Lindon for Berlin in order to have an audience of the Emperor and to confer with the Berlin Foreign Office. He will sail tor Genoa on May 23 to assume his poet as German Consul-General in Cairo.

A marriage will take place in July between Mr. Ernest Tatham Richmond, Ministry of Public Works, Cairo, son of Sir William Blake Richmond, K.C.B., R.A., of Beavor-lodge, Hammersmith, and Margaret Muriel, daughter of Mr. Henry James Lubbock, of 74, Eaton- place, S.W.

Captain H. B. Protheroe Smith, 21st Lancers, Commandant M.M.P. in Egypt, has taken over the duties of Acting Provost Marshal vice Captain C. Burroughs, M.M.P., Assistant Provost Marshal, who has been transferred to the home establishment.
Dr. Thomas Bogie Hamilton, M.B., Ch.B., has been appointed legal medical adviser to the Native Tribunals.

Mr John Joannides, manager of the Bank of Athens at Alexandria, has been promoted to the rank of Commander of the Order of the Holy Saviour by the King of the Hellenes. We heartily congratulate our distinguished fellow- citizen on this signal mark of his Sovereign’s esteem.

We regret to announce the death of Helen, the only child of Mr. Franz Reinsperger, the newly appointed manager of the New Khedivial Hotel at Alexandria. Mrs. Reinsperger and the family only arrived at Alexandria from Austria on the 30th ult., and the child, who was eleven months old, fell »H of gastro- enteritis and expired yesterday afternoon at 3 o’clock.

div.head: THE ARCHAEOLOGICAL SOCIETY.
div.p: The annual general meeting of the Alexandria Archaeological Society was held on Saturday, Mr. A. Ralli in the chair, in the absence of H.H. Prince Omar Toussoun, the honorary president After approving the minutes of the meeting of May 2, 1905, the secretary read the report of the society’s labours for the year 1905-6, of which the following is an abridgment:—

The eighth bulletin of the society contains a report by Dr. Borchardt, illustrated by several drawings, on a section of the great building, the ruins of which have been laid bare in the course of the excavations connected with the new quays, near Victoria College. This antique construction, moreover, has been examined, and a plan made of it, which the society intend to publish, with photographs by Ed. Simond Bey and Dr. Breccia. The bulletin contains an able contribution from Mr. Edgar on a vase in the Cairo Museum found at Mendes.and another by Mr. Lefèvre on fourteen epitaphs by Alexandrian monks found at Dekhela, and now in the Alexandria Museum. Other papers are one by Mr. Rubenson on his excavations at Aboussir el Malak; one from Messrs. Grenfell and Hunt on their papyrus finds at Oxhyrynchus; a third from Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield embodying an exhaustive and thoughtful study of the complicated problem of Alexandrian topography, while Dr. Breooia throws much light on the rains of Hadra, the Chatby Necropolis, the discoveries of Prince Toussoun at Maamourah and the other fields.
During the year under review sixteen new members had been added to the society.

It is hoped to erect the tablet to the memory of the late Dr. Botti, the curator of the Museum, in the coarse of this year. The financial situation is good, there being after paying out P.T. 16.101.2 a cash surplus of P.T. 3,766.7.

The meeting then proceeded with the election of the committee for 1936 7, which will be comprised of the following : Lady Blomfield, Mr. Amb. A. Ralli, Dr. Schiess Pacha, G. Norsa Boy, Admiral Sir M. Blomfield, Mr. E. B. Gould, Dr. Osborne, Poilay Bey, Ed. Simond Bey, Mr. W. P. Chataway, Hamdoullah Emin Paoha, and M. Malaval.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Comme on pouvait s’y attendre à la s~ite de l’henrense issue du conflit d’Akaba, notre marché a accentné sa tendance à la hausse.
Les petites valeurs, qui ont pourtant ces jours derniers causé des surprises déragréables à leurs propriétaires, ont été les favorites du jour.
C’est ainsi que la Delta Land est remontée de 4 1/8 à 4 5/16. le Trust de 1 9/16 à 1 5/8, les Estâtes de 1 3/4 à 1 13/16 et l’Urbaine de 6 1/8 à 6 5/16.
Le Comptoir Financier et Commercial Campos) se relève péniblement de 6 1/32 à 6 1/16.
Ce sont là, avec l’Agricole à 10, les valeurs qui ont été le plus échangées.
La Delta Light, après avait atteint un moment 12 7/16, est revenue à 12 5/16 en clôture.
Par contre, l’Union Foncière finit activement demandée à 6 9/16.
La National Bank est un peu plus faible à 26 1/2.

Notre bourse attend la cote de Londres pour s’engager plus avant. Déjà le taux d’escompte s’y trouve réduit de 4 à 3 1/8 % et le consolidé s’y raffermit toujours davantage. Une nouvelle réduction du taux d’escompte, secondée d’une reprise sur nos valeurs égyptiennes occasionnerait ici un fort mouvement à la hausse.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: Le taux de l’escompte libre à Londres vient d’être, à nouveau, réduit de 1/8 à 3 8/4 pour cent. C’est là un indice que la situation monétaire est décidément en voie d’amélioration.

Au Stock Exchange, hier, le Consolidé angalais a clôturé en reprise de 1/4 de livre à 89 5/8. L’Unifiée a baissé de 1/8 à 104 1/8. La National Bank a regagné 1/8 à 26 1/4. L’Agricole, la Daïra et la Delta Light sont restées invariées à leurs prix précédents.
A Paris, l’action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a encore perdu 1 franc à 772. La Banque d’Athènes est demeurée inchangée à 150.

Encouragé, d’un côté, par la baisse du taux de l'escompte à Londres, e* de l’autre côté, par des nouvelles privées représentant le différend d’Akaba comme virtuellement réglé, notre marché des valeurs a manifesté, ce matin, de bonnes dispositions.

Le mouvement s’est porté principalement sur la National Bank qni, de 26 3/16, a été poussée, presque sans vendeurs, à 26 5/8 pour clôturer à 26 9/16. L’Agricole a également avancé de 9 18/16 à 9 31/32 pour clôturer à 9 15/16. Le Comptoir Financier s’est relevé à 6 1/8 ; l’actien nouvelle à 6.

L’action Crédit Foncier s’est maintenue à 778-779. La Daïra a regagné 1/4 à 17 3/8. La Delta Light est remontée à 12 1/4, Les Jouissances Baux du Caire ont progressé à 264-265 et l’Union Foncière à 6 3/8-7/16.
Le groupe des valeurs hôtelières est resté calme.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont remonté à 4 1/8.

L’action Walker and Meimarachi est toujours à £ 0 3/4. On affirme, toutefois, que la Société a décidé de vendre, à des conditions très avantageuses, la moitié du vaste terrain acheté à côté de l’Agence de France. Elle construirait ses nouveaux magasins sur l’autre moitié, qui serait amplement suffisante. Par oe moyen eUe réaliserait un gros bénéfice immédiat, tout en assurant une économie importante pour la construction de l’immeuble. Si cette nouvelle se confirmait, il faudrait s’at- tendre, à bref délai, à une forte hausse sur ce titre.

Nous avons reçu le rapport imprimé ^u conseil d’administration de la Sooiété Anonyme Agricole et Industrielle d’Egypte, qui a été approuvé par l'assemblée générale ordinaire tenue au Caire le 3 Mai courant.
Il en résulte que lee bénéfices nets de l’exercice clos au 31 Janvier dernier ont été de L.E. 104,013, y compris le solde de L.E. 10,603 reporté de l’exercice précédent.

Après déduction du service des obligations, des frais généraux, de divers autres amortissements, prélèvements pour les fonds de réserve, intérêts statutaires, tantièmes, etc, il est resté L.E. 34,717, que l’assemblée a décidé de répartir à raison de Frs. 47,50 par action de capital et Frs. 45 par part de dividende, en reportant L.E. 9,302 à compte nouveau.

Les fonds de réserve statutaire, extraordinaire et spéciaux s’éstablissent à L.B. 95,600, sans tenir compte des bénéfices reportés à nouveau et de la réserve latente représentée par la plus-value des propriétés de la Société.
Il est à noter que, depuis sa fondation, la Société à acheté 58,062 feddans pour L.E. 1,752,450 et revenda 16,976 feddans pour L.E. 784 485, ce qui a donné un bénéfice d’environ LE 331,000.

A l’assemblée générale des actionnaires de l’Egyptian Constructions Ltd. qui s’est tenue avant-hier au siège social au Caire, le président a exposé que la Société a déjà en main quelques affaires, dont les plus importantes sont celles de la construction de l’annexe du Savoy Hôtel, appartenant à la Nungovich Hotels Co., et des Savoy Chambers, à l’Egyptian Estâtes Co.
La Société a également contracté avec l’administration dos Chemins de fer, ainsi qu’avec divers particuliers pour des constructions aux environs du Caire et d’Alexandrie.
Carnet de l’actionnaire.

Les porteurs d’actions de la Société des Tramways d’Alexandrie sont informés que les dividendes de Frs. 6.25 par aotion privilégiée et de Frs. 2.75 par action de dividende seront payables à partir du 1er Juin prochain, à la Banque Ottomane, contre présentation du coupon N° 8.
— Conformément à la décision prise par l’assemblée générale du 2 Mai courant, les coupons suivants de la Crown Brewery seront payés à partir du 1er Juin prochain, à la Banque Ottomane :
Exercice 1905. — Coupon de capital N° 6 à raison de Frs. 10 ;
Exercice 1905.— Coupon de jouissance N° 6 à raison de Frs. 5 ;
Plus le coupon de jouissance en suspens de l’exercice 1904. à raison de Frs. 5, contre remise du coupon N° 5 et coupons antérieurs.
LA MENDICITE
Depuis que’ques jours, une bande de mendiants, apparemment de nationalité allemande, exploite la bonne foi des. alexandrins.

Il serait bon que cet état de choses prenne fin, notre ville devient une vraie cour des miracles, envahie de mendiants de toute nationalité et de tout genre. Les consuls qui se sont si bien accordés pour réprimer divers abus, ne pourraient-ils: s’entendre sur une question qui nous semble avoir, aussi, son importance?

div.head: Municipalité d’Alexandrie. AVIS
div.p: Le Vendredi 18 Mai courant à 4 h. aprèsmidi le Musée procédera à la vente aux enchères publiques près de la colline de Chatby d’une quantité de 70m3. environ des pierres extraites des fouilles de Chatby, ainsi que de 50 pierres de taille.
Les acheteurs devront déposer le 10% de la valeur de la marchandise achetée, au moment de la vente et effectuer le paiement intégral à la Caisse Municipale le lendemain du jour de l’adjudication.
Ils auront à supporter les droits de carrière au profit de la ville et devront enlever les pierres achetées dans un délai de dix jours, sous peine de folle enchère pour compte de l’adjudicataire.

div.head: Public Work Department Insspection General of Irrigation, LOWER EGYPT.
div.p: The river level having kept up better than anticipated, the commencement of ordinary summer Rotations has been postponed till the 18th (eighteenth) instant and rotations on rice canals till the 16th (sixteenth) instant.

div.head: Royal Insurance Company.
div.p: Messrs. Haselden and Co., Egyptian Agents for the Royal Insurance Company of Liverpool hereby beg to inform their clients that having regard to the widespread uneasiness which the San Francisco disaster has created in the minds of the public generally, the Directors of the Royal Insurance Company have made the following official announcement: —

"The Royal Insurance Company has learnt by cablegram from its Manager at San Francisco that the area of the recent disaster involves a possible liability of £ 1,350,000 (6,750,000 dols.). Having regard however to the large balance at the credit of Profit and Loss at the end of 1904, and the profitable results of last year’s operations, the payments which will have to be made in connection with this liability will not necessitate any redaction in the Fire and Reserve Funds of the Company.”

It is anticipated that when the Manager of the Company at San Francisco has been able to look closely into the position it will transpire: that the Company's losses will be appreciably less than the figure mentioned.

div.head: RUSSIA'S NEW PARLIAMENT.
div.p: CRY FOR AMNESTY.
St. Petersburg,May 12.

The members of the Duma have declined an invitation of the St. Petersburg Municipality to a reception on the ground that entertainment is impossible until the amnesty to political prisoners has been granted.

DUMA. - At to day’s sitting congratulatory messages were read from the political prisoners in the gaols ; the members cheered, shouting "amnesty” "amnesty” : the Duma adopted a motion thanking the prisoners.
(Reuters)
St. Petersburg,May 12.
The Duma has made a manifestation in favour of an amnesty.
(Havas)
St. Petersburg,May 13.

In the Duma, yesterday, after vigorous speeches expatiating on the sufferings of the people, the committee was instructed, in drafting a reply to the speech from the Throne, to include the request for full amnesty and the abolition of the death penalty.
(Reuter)

div.head: ALEXANDRIA HORSE SHOW.
div.p: Encouraged by the success of their efforts last year, the organising committee held their second annual Horse Show at the Alexandria Hippodrome last Saturday. The Show was, if anything, a greater success than the previous one, and the fixture may now be confidently regarded as being an annual ore The institution is certainly one which deserves every support, both public and private, as there is no doubt that that such Shows serve as an encouragement for the introduction of a better breed of horses and instil a healthy spirit of rivalry among horse-owners and drivers, which cannot but be productive of good results. It has been suggested to us that the Show should receive official support, and we see no reason why at least the Municipality, which gives prizes for horse and boat races, should not similarly give prizes for certain classes in the Horse Show. H.H. Prince Omar Toussonn has set a good example by offering Gold Medal to the winner of the largest number of points, and the coveted prize went to Mr. J. Taylor, who was in charge of Mr. E. A. Benachi’s exhibits. With the exception of a single one, the whole of the classes on the programme were filled, and the entries exceeded those of last year by ten. An even more gratifying result would have been attained, we think, had the committee given wider publicity to the Show, which indubitably owes most of its success to the uni g energy of Mr. J, Taylor, who deserves the thanks and congratulations of all lovers of horses. The Show was opened by H. H. Prince Omar Toussonn at 9 30 a.m. and dosed at 6.30 p.m., there being a large attendance of the public all day. Those who came early took luncheon on the ground, a well-laid repast being provided by the management of the Khedivial Hotel.

As regards the exhibits, we were pleased to see that H. H. Prince Omar Toussonn and Prince Mohamed Ibrahim were both successful in three events, making a good display with their racing stock. The winner in the light weight hack class, M. Metaxopulos’ Zariff, was one of the finest horses in the Show. In Class 7. the whole of the three prizes were carried off by young Master Zeryudachi, who is a promising horseman. The jumping was far better all round than last year, and for this Mr. Lian secured no less than three first prizes, his horse jumping in very fine style. General Thurneyseen Pacha, the veteran sportsman, was second in this class. The Egyptian Police made a good show, their exhibits eliciting general admiration for the way in which they were turned out. In the governess cars class Miss Sinadino was first and displayed great grace in her handling of the reins. The ladies' back class was particularly successful, there being eight entries, Miss Lang Anderson easily secured first with her hack, whose paces, trot, and canter wove perfect. Class 18 (horses in single harness) was a decided advance on last year both as regards quality c-f horse and turn-out. Mr. E. A. Benachi’s dark chestnut secured the blue rosette for this, the animal showing extraordinary action without the application of any torture A olass which deserves every encouragement is surely the cab-horse class. There was a goodly number of entries and the exhibitors made a great show.The British Military Police, in Class 29, showed a fine group of horses, smartly turned out, and the winner tally deserved his prize. In Class 19, for cobs, the winners gave the impression of being well trained and they were splendidly driven, their machine-like movements beiDg the admiration of all. A nice quality of horse likely to make a fine pair with more training were those of Mrs. Rees. There was a small entry for Class 16, but the winner would take a lot of beating ; he showed gold all-round quality and was well driven by Baron Menasce. Mr. Ed. Benachi was the winner of the four-in-hands class with a magnificent team driven in fine style by Mr. J. Taylor, who turned them about into any figure asked by the judges. For the last event (tandems) there were only two entries, and here again Mr. Benachi was successful with a very fine pair, driven by Mr. Taylor, which were greatly admired for their bearing. Mr. Benachi’s stable, as before stated, won the Gold Medal for the largest number of points, four firsts and two seconds going to him. The next most successful competitor was Mr Godfrey Barker, who took the greatest interest in the Show.

div.head: THE SUEZ CANAL
div.p: In the series “Round the Empire" in the "World,” the Suez Canal forms the subject of an interesting article. Daring the past twenty years, says the writer, steady spade-work baa been constantly going on. Id 1870 the canal bad a depth of only twenty-six feet three inches, and a bottom width of seventy-two feet In 1887 8 it was deepened by half a metre, and the bottom width was gradually increased to a hundred and eight feet. The curves in the channel were at the same time rounded off, in order to accelerate the speed of vessels.
INCREASING IN DEPTH.

During the years 1898-1904 passing stations were constructed eight hundred and twenty yards in length, at intervals of three miles, with a bottom width of a hundred and fifty feet. At this time also the depth of the channel was increased all along to twenty-nine and a-half feet; and in 1902 ships drawing twenty-six feet three inches of water were allowed to use the Canal. Work is still in progress with the intention of increasing the depth to thirty-one feet, and the bottom width to a hundred and twenty-eight feet.when it will be possible to increase the rata of speed from six miles to nine miles an hour, reducing the average time of passage from eighteen to twelve hours. The steamer in which the writer came through the Canal took sixteen and a- half hours to effect the journey. Battleships can at present go through if they dismount their heavy gang into lighters, and coal at the far end of the Canal.
WIDENING PROJECT.

When a depth of thirty one feet is obtained, even the Dreadnougth could make the passage carrying her ten twelve inch guns on their mountings, If the directors will be sufficiently far-sighted to incur the expense of widening the Canal throughout its length, by connecting the existing passing stations, and thus give continuous surface width of three hundred feet, with a bottom width of a hundred and fifty feet, this would accomplish the duplication of the Canal, and vessels could pass each other without losing time at the passing stations. Tying np in a passing station means the loss of at least an hoar. It has been estimated that the cost of the proposed extension would not exceed a -million pounds—a capital expenditure which could not fail to be remunerative, and would set at rest for all time the construction of a rival canal.
TRAFFIC RETURNS.

If this is to be done no time should be lost, as the traffic is certain to increase in corresponding proportion to the annual development of the world’s trade and shipping. From the first year of opening the Canal, when the transit receipts amounted to only 54,460fcs, down to 1904, when the receipts were 115,818,479fcs, «here has been a steady, continuous, annual growth of traffic; and what is special'y to be noted is that each reduction of transit dues has been nearly always immediately followed by an increase in receipts. It will be interesting to see if this increase will be maintained during the current year, now that the tariff has been reduced to the unprecedentedly low rate of seven francs seventy-five centimes per ton.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: London,May 5.
The Inniskilling Dragoons will embark at Queenstown about the 13th inst. for Alexandria. The same liner will also convey the U. Battery, Royal Horse Artillery.

It is officially announced that the 2nd Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers (the 1st Battalion of which is in Egypt), Buttevant, and the 2nd Battalion Royal Irish Regiment, Fermoy, will exchange stations on the 14th September next.

We understand that Brig-General F. S. F. Stokes, commanding 17th Brigade, Belfast, has been selected for the appointment of commander of the infantry brigade at Gibraltar, and in the ordinary coarse will be promoted to the rank of major general. Whilst the 17th Brigade regrets losing such a considerate brigadier, all ranks are pleased to learn of bis promotion, which is recognition of merit and professional capacity, and administrative ability. General Stokes began his military career in the 83rd County Dublin Regiment- now the 1st Battalion Royal Irish Rifles—in April, 1870, was promoted captain in 1878, major in 1885, and became lieutenant colonel in 1895. He was appointed to the command of the 83rd Regimental District, Belfast, on New Year’s Day, 1901, and to the command of the 17th Brigade, with the temporary rank of brigadier general, on the 1st Jane last. He has held several important staff appointments in India and elsewhere, and saw considerable active service in the Suakin Expedition, 1885, including the action of Hasheen and the destruction of Tamai (medal with clasp, and Khedive’s star), and prior to that he served with the 83rd in the Natal Field Force daring the war of 1881.

At the end of this month, Colonel LS Mellor will complete his period in command of the S7th Regimental District, Omagh, which will be absorbed into the North Irish Grouped Regimental District Colonel Mellor passed his regmental service in the King’s Liverpool Regiment; and was with the King’s in the Afghan War, 1878-9 (medal with clasp), and the South African War, 1899, including the actions of Rietfontein, Lombard’s Kop, and the defence of Ladysmith (mentioned twice in despatches, Queen’s medal with clasp)
Captain J.H.H. Jones, Royal Garrison Artillery, on returning home from Hong Kong, where he was Instructor of Gunnery, has been posted to No. 10 Company, Cork Harbour.
The Cape Squadron is to be abolished as an independent command and amalgamated with the East Indies Squadron, and commanded by a vice-admiral.

The Fourth Cruiser Squadron, which visits the North Atlantic and West Indian waters periodically, is to be reorganised into a more formidable fighting force. At an early date, it will be composed exclusively of armoured cruisers.
The gradual concentration of our naval strength in home waters points to one conclusion, —the apparently inevitable conflict with Germany for naval superiority.

div.head: MOUNT TROODOS'
div.p: A limited number of paying guests can be received by a Lady daring the Summer Months. Cyprus is 24 hours by sea from Port Said. Troodos 6,406 feet above the sea is a delightful and healthy, place amongst the pine forests where the troops and Government Officials spend the hot season.
Terms 2 1/2 Guineas per week. For further particulars apply to Miss YOUNG, Nikosia, or to the Editor.
Further Particulars

Position. The pine covered slopes of Mount Troodos where Miss Young has a camp, are about 6406 feet above the sea ; the troops stationed in Cyprus and the Principal Government Officials live there during the hot season from about June till October.

Routes. Troodos is about 35 miles from the port of Limassol from which there is a good carriage road to Platres 31 m. Beyond Platres the road is good but steep and from that point people often ride on mules for the rest of the journey. There is also an excellent road from the Capital, Nicosia, by which persons going from that side of the Island drive all the way (about 16 miles).
Climate. The climate is very dry and healthy, in the daytime it is delightful; the nights, especially after the end of August, are often rather cold.

Dress. There is a good deal of red dust on the hills and ladies should be provided with washing skirts. White is a good deal worn, but it is advisable to have some brown, fawn, or dust-coloured linen, dresses which do not shew dust stains as the washing is not first rate. A warm woollen “coat and skirt” costume is also indispensable.
Rides. There are plenty of delightful rides amongst the hills, but the roads and bridle paths are too steep for bicycles. Mules and ponies can be hired for the season.
Expeditions. Places of interest to be reached on mule or potty hack are Kykko Monastery, Kalopanaioti, Trooditissa Monastery, etc.
Games. There is a Tennis Club with two good courts, there are also one or two private tennis and croquet grounds.
Church. An English Church Service is held twice on Sundays at the Regimental Recreation Room.
Water. The water supply is good and the drinking water pure and wholesome.
Money. Drafts on the Imperial Ottoman Bank and English gold and notes accepted.
By June the railway which runs from Famagusta to Nikosia will lie extended to within 30 miles of Nikosia.
